Graphical Abstract
Highlights
 First time, we synthesized and studied the electrochemical properties of Sol-gel Mg
and Co doped SnO2
 Small particle size of 5.5 nm was observed for Co -SnO2 than < 10 nm for Zn and Mg
–SnO2
 Exhibited specific capacity of 573 mAh g-1 (83% capacity retention) for Co -SnO2 at
60 mA g-1
 At 1000 mA g-1, high specific capacity of 415 mAh g-1 was obtained for Co-SnO2

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
In this paper, we show that magnesium and cobalt doped SnO2 (Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2) nanostructures have profound influence on the discharge capacity and coulombic efficiency of lithium ion batteries (LIBs) employing pure SnO2 and zinc doped SnO2 (Zn-SnO2) as benchmark materials. The materials were synthesized via sol-gel technique. The structural, chemical and morphological characterization indicates that the Zn, Mg and Co dopants were effectively implanted into the SnO2lattice and that Co doping significantly reduced the grain growth. The electrochemical performances of the nanoparticles were investigated using galvanostatic cycling, cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy
(EIS). The Co-SnO2 electrode delivered a reversible capacity of around 575mAhg -1 at the 50th cycle with capacity retention of ~83% at 60 mAg-1current rate. A capacity of ~415 mAhg-1 when cycling at 103 mA g-1and >60% improvement in coulombic efficiency compared to the pure compound clearly demonstrate the superiority of Co-SnO2electrodes.The improved electrochemical properties are attributed to the reduction in particle size of the material up to a few nanometers, which efficiently reduced the distance of lithium diffusion pathway and reduction in the volume change by alleviating the structural strain caused during the Li+ intake/outtake process. The EIS analyses of the electrodes corroborated the difference in electrochemical performances of the electrodes: the Co-SnO2 electrode showed the lowest resistance at different voltages during cycling among other electrodes.
Keywords: Energy Storage Materials, Electrodes, Electrochemical Properties, Strain Engineering.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Lithium ion batteries (LIBs) are superior over other charge storage devices because of
their high energy density, low internal resistance, no-memory effect, eco-friendliness and safety concerns. However, reversibility and prolonged cycle life are still issues in LIB scenario; and towards this end, countless efforts with varied choice of materials are undertaken to optimize an ideal electrode[1, 2]. The commercial carbonaceous anode material, such as graphite, has low theoretical capacity (372mAhg-1) and to be replaced to further increase the energy density. In this context, tin oxide [3] as an anode material is highly desirable in view of its high abundance, low operation potential, high electrical conductivity, theoretical capacity twice that of graphite (~781 mAh g-1), as well as other chemical and physical properties[4].Superiority of SnO2as an anode materials was identified
during early work by Dhan et al [5] and Aurbach et al [3], later by various other researchers[4, 6, 7]. However, drastic volume changes observed in SnO2 electrodes during lithiation and de-lithiation processes lead to poor capacity and cycling performance. Two strategies can be followed to solve these problems,viz. (i) nano-crystallization of the electrode material, which would shorten the diffusion length of lithium ions within the active material thereby enhancing the reversibility and minimizing the volume change; and (ii) the use of suitable matrix/composites/dopant, which would buffer the volume changes while enabling efficient charge transport. In this regard, many morphologies and architectures such as nanoparticles[3, 8],nanotubes[911], nanowires[12, 13], nanorods[14], nanocables[15], nanofibers[16], nanosheets[17],hollow spheres[18, 19], composites[20-26] and dopants such as nitrogen[27], fluorine[28] and Sulphur [29]are shown to have enhanced electrochemical performances. It is to be noted that nitrogen, sulphur and carbon coating can enhance the interfacial stability, which would provide more reaction cites, shorter Li+ diffusion lengths and better electronic conductivity in SnO2, thereby enhancing electrochemical kinetics. However, the N-SnO2 shows moderately low capacity retention, which still need to be improved for its upcoming commercial applications. In this context, Sn based oxide matrixes such as M2SnO4 (M=Mg, Mn, Co, Zn)[30, 31], K2(M, Sn)8O16 (M=Li, Mg, Fe, Mn, Co, In)[32], (M1/2Sb1/2Sn)O4 ( M= V, Fe, In) [33, 34], ASnO3 (A-Ca, Sr, Ba)[35-37], Y2Sn2O7[38], Li2SnO3[39] and composite Snoxides[40, 41] have also been investigated in detail. Further, during the past few years, various one-dimensional nanostructure, branched hetero-nanostructures such as SnO2-Fe2O3, SnO2-TiO2, SnO2-In2O3, SnS2 were studied for wide range of applications [42, 43]. Furthermore, SnO2 doped with Sb, In, Al, Fe, Sn, Ni, Mo and Zn have been investigated as anode materials [44-49]. Among different metal doped SnO2 (represented as M-SnO2) as mentioned above the Mo-SnO2 has also been found suitable as an cathode material [50] for
LIBs. These studies suggest that high electronic conductivity achieved through doping can improve the cyclability and stability of the electrodes due to efficient Li diffusion during electrochemical process. The Zn-SnO2, Ni-SnO2 and Ce-SnO2 have been widely studied for various applications such as gas sensors, photocatalytic and optoelectronic applications[5153]. Even though the Zn-SnO2 has been studied for its electrochemical performance for different applications, a detailed analysis of its electrode performance and the effect of reduction in particle size which has been reported to be beneficial to increase the kinetic properties of Li uptake and removal, is much scarce in the literature [54]. Also the Mg incorporated SnO2 matrix has been less explored as an active electrode for Lithium batteries. On the other hand the Co doped SnO2 material has been identified as an effective electrode material for LIBs [55] when compared with bare SnO2 since the Co-Sn interactions particularly stabilize the electrode species by the formation of Co-Sn intermetallic species during the reversible cycling [56-58].The effect of such interactions of Co-Sn matrix has been well studied in the literature using different spectroscopic techniques [57]. It has been reported that the cut off voltage for the effective electrochemical intercalation reactions of the SnO2 and doped SnO2 materials also depends on its electrochemical performances [27, 56]. The SnO2 materials when cycled above 1V up to 2V the reversible conversion reaction from Sn to SnO2 occurs resulting in poor cyclability of this material. In this regard the study on the electrochemical performance of the pure and Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 within the voltage window of 0.005-1V attracts special interest.
In this scenario it has been anticipated that Co2+ doping in SnO2 would have dramatic
effects on the LIB performance due to the dopant’s electrochemical properties. Using ZnSnO2 as a benchmark material, we hereby show that Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2 offer impressive improvements in the discharge capacity and coulombic efficiency in LIBs over the previously reported dopants within the voltage range of 0.005-1V. The major concern of the present
study is a detailed comparison and analysis of the electrochemical properties of the doped SnO2 to identifies the influence of the different dopants on the SnO2 matrix to favor high discharge capacity and coulombic efficiency of LIBs.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The Zn, Co and Mg doped SnO2 compounds were synthesized by sol-gel technique.
In a typical synthesis, 0.9 M SnCl2·2H2O was dissolved in 4 M ethylene glycol dimethyl ether at ambient temperature. Then 1M citric acid was added to the above solution and it is dissolved at 50ºC. Next, aqueous solutions containing 0.1 M each of Zn (NO3)2·6H2O, Co (CH3COO)2·4H2O and Mg(OH)2 was separately added to the above solution to prepare Zn, Co, and Mg doped SnO2, respectively. After the addition of different dopants, the solutions were stirred for 5 h at 80ºC (to obtain a clear solution), which was maintained at 100ºC for few hours till a thick gel was formed. The gel were dried in an oven for one week and subsequently transferred to crucibles and calcined at ~350ºC for 3 h to obtain the final products. In order to get the better comparison of the electrochemical properties, the cation dopant concentration has been restricted to be 10 wt% of the Sn concentration for all the samples and also the present study reveals only the surface level cation doping in to the SnO2 host. Alcantara et.al had reported that the dopant concentration about 10wt% of the Sn concentration exhibits better capacity retention within the voltage window of 0.2-0.9V [55]. Hence in the present work the dopant concentration has been maintained as 10wt% (of Sn) for all dopants. We note higher metal ion doping will reduces overall theoretical capacity with in 1.0V due to alloy-reaction.
The crystal structure of the compounds was examined by X-ray diffraction ((λ=1.54Å,
Philips X’PERT MPD unit, PANalytical) using CuKα radiation and the diffractograms were analyzed using Rietveld refinement via TOPAS (v3.1). Morphology of the sample was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JEOL-JSM 6390) and transmission
electron microscope (TEM) (JEOL-JEM 2010F), respectively. Brunauer, Emmett and Teller method (Micrometrics, TriStar 3000) was used to investigate the surface area of the obtained samples. The surface chemical compositions of the prepared compounds were analyzed by Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an AXIS ultra DLD spectrometer (KratosAnalytica). A standard monochromatic Al-Ka excitation source (1486.6 eV) was employed. The binding energy (BE) scale was calibrated by measuring the reference peak of C1s (BE =284.6 eV). The XPS data was analyzed using casa XPS software.
Details on the slurry/electrode preparation and assembly of the battery are as in the
previous publications [38, 59]. The fabricated batteries were electrochemically evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) by using computer controlled Mac-pile II system (Bio-logic, France) at a scan rate of 0.058 mVs-1 and galvanostatic cycling (GC) by using Bitrode battery tester (model SCN, Bitrode, USA), at a constant current density of 60 mA g-1, respectively. The batteries were tested by GC and CV in the potential range of 0.005-1.0 V vs Li. Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopic (EIS) measurements of the coin cell were carried out with a Solartron impedance/gain-phase analyzer (model SI 1255) coupled with a potentiostat (SI 1268) at room temperature in the frequency range, 180000–0.003 Hz with an AC signal amplitude of 10 mV. The impedance data were analyzed using Z-view software (version 2.2, Scribner Assoc., Inc. USA)[59, 60].

sections.heading: Results and Discussions
sections.text:
The XRD pattern of the sol-gel derived pure SnO2 and its Rietveld refined plot is
shown in Fig. 1 (a, b). All the diffraction peaks of the pure SnO2are indexed to the tetragonal structure with P42/mnm (136) space group. The refined lattice parameters were a = 4.746Å, c= 3.192Å, which are in agreement with the reported values [61-63]and JCPDS pattern (#41- 1445; a=4.738Å and b=3.187Å). The average crystallite size determined using the TOPAS software is 10 nm. The quasi-Gaussian (+Lorentzian) type broadened peaks suggests particle
size greatly reduced in accordance with the average crystallite size when compared with sharp Lorentzian peaks of bulk material reported elsewhere [64].The XRD patterns of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 nanoparticles are displays in Fig. 2 (a). All the diffraction peaks of the doped SnO2compounds can be indexed to the tetragonal structure with space group P42/mnm(136), which is consistent with the pure SnO2 pattern as shown in Fig.1 (a). No other peaks were observed in the XRD pattern of the Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2sample indicating that all the dopant metals were effectively implanted into the SnO2 lattice without affecting the phase and structure of the pure SnO2 compounds. The Co doped SnO2 showed broader XRD peaks than the other compounds suggesting size reduction in respective samples. Fig. 2 (b-d) illustrates that Rietveld refinement plot of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 compounds. The lattice parameters of the compounds obtained from the refined XRD pattern are a= 4.742Å, c= 3.194Å, which do not appreciably differ from the pure SnO2 and are in very good agreement with JCPDS data (#41-1445). The similarity of the lattice constants were observed for doped and pure SnO2shows that dopants are adequately incorporated in the SnO2 lattice without any changes in the structure of the parent matrix. The successful incorporation of the dopants into the rutile SnO2 structure is attributed to the similarity in ionic radius of the Zn2+ (0.088 nm), Mg2+ (0.086 nm) and Co2+ (0.079 nm) with that of Sn4+ (0.083 nm) ions.The crystallite size of the compounds is 12 nm for Zn-SnO2, 11 nm for MgSnO2 and 6 nm for Co-SnO2. The Mg and Zn doped SnO2 shows slightly higher crystallite size than the pure SnO2 whereas Co-SnO2showed lower crystallite size; these are consistent with the line broadening observed in the XRD pattern. The BET surface area of Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2 were~40, ~35, and ~92 (±0.2) m 2/g, respectively.
The surface chemical states of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 was examined by XPS.
Fig. 3 (a-i) shows XPS spectra of Zn, Mg, Co, Sn and O1s elements. Zn 2p spectrum exhibits
two peaks at 1021.98 and 1044.98 eV, corresponding to Zn 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, attributed to the presence of Zn in the compound in divalent state[65]. The Sn 3d shows two major peaks at 486.68 eV and 495.18 eV belonging to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2states with a peak difference of 8.5 eV[37]. Two peaks are observed for O 1s, the first peak at 530.58 eV attributed to Sn-O-Sn and the later peak at 531.38 eV, belongs to Zn-O bonding[65]. Moreover the O 1s spectrum is slightly broadened in the high energy state which can be attributed to the OH species in H2O molecule present in the sample. The Mg 2p spectrum shows a peak at 50.1 eV which corresponds to Mg2+[66]states while the Sn 3d spectrum shows two peaks at 486.1 and 494.6 eV, belong to Sn 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 (peak difference-8.5 eV), respectively. The O 1s spectrum consists of two peaks at 530.58 eV belong to Sn-O-Sn and the other one at 531.38 eV due to the OH species in H2O molecule. The Co spectrum consists of two peaks: the peak at 781.59 eV belongs to Co 2p3/2 state and the other peak at 800.99 eV corresponds to Co 2p1/2[67]. The Sn 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 states belongs to the peak located at the binding energies 486.39 and 494.89 eV, respectively, with the peak difference of 8.5 eV. The O 1s spectrum shows a peak at 530.59 eV corresponds to Sn-O-Sn, which is consistent with the Zn and Mg doped spectrum. All the Sn3d spectrum indicates that the Sn element is in the tetravalent oxidation state and the binding energy values are almost equal to the pure SnO2 (data not shown), confirming that all the dopants does not alter the SnO2phase and structures, which is consistent with XRD data..Based on the above results, it has been affirmed that the di-valent metal dopants such as Zn, Mg and Co have successfully incorporated into the SnO2 nanostructures without disturbing the parent matrix.
Fig. 4 (a-c) shows the SEM images of the Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 compounds.
All the images were captured at sub-micron range (2 µm). The Zn-SnO2and Co-SnO2show
agglomerated particles, whereas Mg-SnO2 displays a sheet type of non-uniform particles. In order to get a better insight on the morphology of the doped SnO2 samples, TEM analyses were carried out.
The TEM micrographs of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 compounds are shown in Fig.
5(a-i), which provides more details about structure and size of the particles. The micrographs of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 show spherical particles with an average diameter of ~10 nm for the first two and ~5 nm for the Co analogue, these observations are in very good agreement with the XRD results. In addition, the lattice fringe d-spacing of 0.33 nm can be ascribed for Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 nanoparticles corresponding to the(110) plane, which is marked in Fig. 5 (b, e, h). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 consists of polycrystalline rings, which is consistent with SnO2 rutile structure as shown in Fig. 5(c, f, i). All the SAED patterns are marked with corresponding (hkl) planes. The high resolution lattice images show that the Co-SnO2 sample has comparatively lesser agglomerated and forms well defined grain boundaries when compared with the Zn and Mg doped samples, which is also evident from the well resolved rings that formed in the SAED pattern.
Fig. 6 (a-d) shows galvanostatic cycling results of pure and Zn, Mg, Co doped SnO2
samples when cycled within the potential range of 0.005-1.0 V with a current density of 60 mAg-1. First charge-discharge cycle of all the compounds are shown in Fig. 6 (a). During the first cathodic scan two peaks were noticed around 0.85 V and 0.5 V. The former peak belongs to solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film formation that occurs from electrolyte decomposition and the other due to the reduction process of SnO2 to metallic Sn. The other small peak around 0.25 V originates from the lithium alloying reactions with the formation of
LixSn (0  x  4.4). The first anodic scan of all the compounds showed an oxidation peak at ~0.5 V, corresponding to the de-alloying reaction of LixSn.
SnO2 + 2Li ++ 2e-SnO + Li2O (1) SnO + 2Li+ + 2e- Sn + Li2O (2) Sn + xLi+ + xe-LixSn (0  x 4.4) (3) Galvanostatic cyclic performances of pure SnO2, Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2
compounds are shown in Fig. 7 (a-d) as cycle number vs capacity. The first discharge capacities of SnO2, Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2 electrodes were~1945,~1931, ~1762 and ~1528 mAh g-1 and their corresponding initial charge capacitieswere~508, ~562, ~536 and ~639 mAh g-1giving rise to the initial coulombic efficiencies as~26, ~29, ~30 and ~42%, respectively. Here the columbic efficiency has been calculated as the effective charge capacity divided by discharge capacity assuming the maximum coulumbic efficiency is 100 percentages. The initial irreversible capacity loss of the compounds is~1437, ~1369, ~1226 and ~889 mAh g-1for SnO2, Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2, respectively. The SnO2 matrix exhibits very high initial discharge capacity which is higher than the predicted value due to the alloying de-alloying reactions which originates from the decomposition of some portion of the Li2O phase to form the SnOx phase upon de-lithiation, along with de-alloying of LixSn, which leads to unexpected high capacity of an ordered mesoporous SnO2 material[56]. The high initial irreversible capacity loss (ICL) of the compounds could be attributed to the formation of Li2O and SEI film formation which arises from the decomposition of solvent in the electrolyte. However, in the present studies Co doped SnO2 shows lower ICL values when compared with other dopants. The highest columbic efficiency of Co-SnO2 might be ascribed to the lower particle size which can minimize the diffusion lengths for ionic and electronic transports and also to the minimum volume change that induced by the stable structure after Co incorporation in to the SnO2matrix allowing most of its Sn atoms to undergo complete reversible alloying-de-alloying reaction with lithium[68, 69].Further Co ion doping seems to
be the best choice as it stimulates high reversibility towards the anode matrix as observed in the case of Co2Mo3O8 compounds[70].
The Co-Sn interactions due to the formation of the intermetallic phase plays a major
role for the better performance of the Co incorporated SnO2[55]. In the present study reveals that the Mg incorporated SnO2 also exhibits very high capacity in line with the Co doped SnO2 materials. (The typical charge-discharge curves with selected cycles (2, 10, 30 and 50) of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 compounds are shown in Fig. 6 (b-d). In all the compounds, the coulombic efficiency of the second cycle was found to be >95 %, indicating the retrieval of high reversibility. Zn-SnO2 compound shows rapid capacity fading during the following cycles in both discharge and charge states. Whereas, Mg and Co doped SnO2 compounds show moderately low capacity fading up to 10 cycles and then started fading gradually.
The SnO2 and Zn-SnO2 exhibits a discharge capacity of 552 and 601mAh g -1 at 2nd
cycle, and then started fading rapidly to 330 and 352 mAh g-1 at 50th cycle. The Mg doped SnO2 exhibits the 2 nd cycle discharge capacity of589 mAh g-1, after which the capacity fading was minimized, showing a capacity of 526 mAh g-1 (capacity retention of 89 %) at 30th cycle and 485 mAh g-1 at the end of the 50thcycle.Co doped SnO2 compound exhibits a second cycle capacity of 697mAh g-1 which gradually reduced to 632 mAh g-1at the 30th cycle with the capacity retention of 91%. Further, upon cycling the reversible capacity of the compound was decreased to 573 mAh g-1at 50th cycle. Overall, the obtained capacity retention for SnO2, Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2 compounds was 60, 59, 82 and 83 %, respectively at 50 th cycle. The SnO2 and Zn doped SnO2 exhibited almost the same trend in capacity retention and fading rate during the electrochemical cycling. However, the discharge capacity value of Zn doped SnO2 was slightly higher than that of pure SnO2[54]. In the SnO2 matrix the cut off voltage also plays a prominent role to get a better capacity and minimizing the capacity fading. In this regard the voltage window from 0.005 to 1 observed to be a better choice in
the case of SnO2 in order to avoid the reversible conversion reaction from Sn to SnO2[27]. Capacity loss could be attributed to the unadorned volume changes of the aggregated Sn particles upon cycling, which leads to pulverization of the electrode. Nevertheless, pure SnO2 prepared by sol-gel method exhibits high reversible capacity compared with other methods reported in the literature [22, 47, 71-74].Also, Mg and Co doped SnO2 showed high capacity retention with good cycling stability. The observed capacity for Mg and Co doped SnO2 shows much higher value than that of the reported literature values of F, Al, Ni and Sb doped SnO2[28, 44, 46, 54, 75]. Significantly, the Co doped SnO2 shows the highest capacity than all the other dopants. Apart from the Co-Sn intermetallic interactions, the better cycling performance and higher capacity of the Co doped SnO2is due to the reduction in particle size and buffering effect by restricting the volume change that occurs during the alloying/dealloying process of the Li ions on Sn sites. Similar to the Co-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 also exhibits improved cycling stability with good capacity retention after extended cycling than pure SnO2 and Zn-SnO2 samples. The samples exhibit high and stable coulumbic efficiency in CoSnO2 and Mg-SnO2 samples.
Inorder to investigate the rate performance, the SnO2, Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-
SnO2electrodes were subjected to the galvanostatic cycling at current densities of 100, 200, 500, 700 and 1000 mAg-1 for 30 cycles each. It is a well known fact that the specific capacity decreasesgradually with the increase in current desnity.The observed specific capacity values of all compounds at different current desnities are listed in Table 2. The Zn doped SnO2 exhibits higher capacity values of 658 mAh g-1 at 100 mAg-1 than SnO2 (445 mAh g -1), however, after increasing the cuttent desnity from 200-1000 mAg-1, the specific capacity of the SnO2 and Zn-SnO2 reveled almost same capacity and the cycling behaviour. Though, when the current density was furthur reduced to 100 mAg-1, the capacity of the SnO2 and Zn-
SnO2 showed fast capacity fading, resulted in poor reproducibility. The Mg-SnO2 reveals the spceific capacity of 672 mAh g-1 at 100 mAhg-1, which is gradually reduced to 304 mAh g-1 at 1000 mAg-1. As the rate goes back to 100 mA g-1, the capacity rebounds to 614 mAh g-1. Neverthless, the Co-SnO2 exhibit the highest reversible capacities of 739, 616, 549, 495 and 413 mAh g-1 at the current densities of 100, 200, 500, 700 and 1000 mA g-1, respectively. In order to understant the ability of the electorde, the cell was switched back to a lower current density of 100 mA g-1, after cycling in a current density of 1000 mAg-1. Interstingly the cell exhibits the highest capacity of 651 mAh g-1 with neglible capacity fading. Although the capacitiesof the compounds are not high at the high current rates, the results indicatesbetter capacity retentionand good stability of the electorde materials than reported in the literature [68]. Such a performance of this material can be attributed to the nanocrystalization and the stable structure that originates afer the incorporation of Co into the SnO2 sites which results in minimum volume change during the Li intercalation-deintercalation reactions. The present observations clearly establish that along with the Co-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 also exhibits better rate capabilities and better capacity retension when compared with bare and Zn-SnO2 samples.Like Co-Sn interactions due to the formation of intermetalic phase, the interaction between Mg-SnO2 may also give some important results.
Fig. 9 (a-c) shows CV curves of the Zn-SnO2, Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2for the first 6
cycles at the scan rate of 58 µV s-1within the potential range of 0.005-1.0 V. First cycle of all the compounds show a reduction peak around at 0.8 V, attributed to the decomposition of electrolyte and related structural transformation of the compound. First cathodic peak at ~0.8 V (Fig. 9 (a)) shows very sharp with larger current, suggesting high irreversible capacity loss in the compound. On the other hand, Mg and Co doped SnO2(Fig. 9 (b, c)) compounds show a broad cathodic peak ~0.8 V with low current, suggesting low irreversible capacity loss which is in good agreements with cycling data. Then, the small cathodic peak~0.5 V corresponds to SEI film formation, after the decomposition of the electrolyte. The reduction peak at~0.15 V in the first cycle of all the compounds are attributed various alloy formation reactions of LixSn. In all the compounds, the peak at ~0.5 V is vanished suggesting that the SEI formation occurs only in the first cycle and the peak at ~0.13 V is slightly shifted in the subsequent cycles and then stabilized around at 0.23V, which can be ascribed to the alloying reactions of Sn with Li (Sn + xLi+ + xe-LixSn (0  x  4.4)).The anodic scans of all the compounds show a peak ~0.55 V belongs to the de-alloying reactions of LixSn. The reduction in peak area that occurs in the peak situated at ~0.2 V in Zn-SnO2 compound after the initial cycle may be attributed to the capacity fading during cycling. The peak area and peak broadening at ~0.2 V in Mg-SnO2(Fig. 9 (b)) remains nearly similar after the initial cycle, which can account for the good capacity retention with considerable capacity fading that observed during cycling reaction. On the other hand, Fig.9 (c) shows an overlapping CV curves after the first cycle (almost identical peaks),can be attributed to the better reversibility of the Co-SnO2compound showing high capacity retention with good stability. All the compounds of CV data are in good complement with the galvanostatic cycling.
Further, in order to investigate the electrochemical performance of pure and Zn, Mg,
Co doped SnO2 compound, EIS measurements were carried out for the fresh cells over the
frequency range of 18 kHz to 3 mHz (Fig.10.a). The results were plotted in the Nyquist plots (Z’ vs -Z”) and the EIS parameters were calculated from the fitted data using equivalent circuit as shown in Fig. 10 (b). The symbols show the original data while solid line represents the fitted profile. The equivalent circuit used for fitting composed of resistance (R), constant phase element (CPE), Warburg impedance (Ws) and intercalation capacitance (Ci).
The resistance includes the contributions from electrolyte, surface film (sf) and charge
transfer (ct) components. The CPE, which includes the contributions of surface film (sf) and double layer (dl) has been used instead of pure capacitor due to the composite nature of the electrodes and notations are similar to the previous reports [21, 76-80]. All the plots of fresh cells showed after resolving exhibits two semicircle in the high-mid frequency which corresponds to Rsf,ct and CPEsf, dl. The α-values (warburg element) of fresh cells of all the compounds vary from 0.32-0.56. The resolved impedance parameters after fitting are tabulated in Table 3. All the plots show two semicircles in the resolved pattern due to the impedance of the surface film and the charge transfer phenomena. From the Table 3 it is clear that the resistance due to the electrolyte dissociation and the surface film shows nearly similar values, while the charge transfer resistance exhibits wide variation among the dopants. The charge transfer resistance is maximum in SnO2 sample and minimum in Co-SnO2 sample. The fresh cell Nyquist plots clearly establish that the facile Li-ion movement is possible with minimum impedance in Co and Mg doped SnO2 sample, which is in line with the previous results. The minimum impedance of the Co-SnO2 accounts its better capacity when compared with other dopant ions.
In order to get a better insight on the lower resistance shown by the Co-
SnO2compared with other dopants (fig.10.a), impedance spectra at different voltages have
been recorded for thefirst discharge. The cells were galvanostatically discharged at a constant current density of 60 mAg-1 to a particular voltage before recording the impedance plot at that voltage. All the plots have been fitted using the Z-View software and portrayed as a 3D scatter in fig 10c. In all the plots the symbols show the measured data and the solid line shows the fitted curve. The resolved parameters have been tabulated in Table 4. At 2V, the surface film resistance has been increased while the charge transfer resistance shows a lower value which is further decreased at 1V when compared with the fresh cell. On the other hand, at 0.8V the surface film and the charge transfer resistance has been increased to a higher value. The first cycle discharge profile shows a peak due to the electrolyte dissociation at 0.8V in the galvanostatic and CV results. This can be correlated with the increase in the values of the surface film and hence the increase in the resistance of the charge transfer component. Again the surface film and the charge transfer resistance shows an increase at 0.6V which may be correlated with component of resistance that arises due to the surface film formation after the electrolyte dissociation. The charge transfer resistance at 0.2 V exhibit lower value than the previous voltages which clearly shows that the Li-Sn alloying reaction occurs at lower voltages in the initial discharge. The high resistance that occurs at 0.005V arises from the alloying reaction, which is in line with the CV results. The CV plot shows that the alloying reaction occurs at 0.13V for the first discharge, which has been shifted to0.23V in the consequent cycles. The impedance plots over different voltages after galvanostatic discharging the cell to the particular voltage shows a decrease in the value of charge transfer component in Co-SnO2 sample to a large extent when compared to the fresh cell results, which accounts for the better capacity of the Co-SnO2 sample when compared with other dopants.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Bare and Zn, Mg, Co doped SnO2 compounds have been synthesized by sol-gel route.
X-ray diffraction pattern of all the compounds revealed the tetragonal structure with P42/mnm (136) space group. There were no secondary peaks observed indicating the proper incorporation of all the dopants in to the SnO2 structure. The TEM micrograph of Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2 showed the spherical nanoparticle with an average diameter of 10 nm. The presences of all the elements and its valance have been verified from the XPS analysis of the samples. The CV results of all the compounds showed Sn alloying and de-alloying reactions of the SnO2 suggesting the reversible nature of the doped SnO2 compounds. The galvanostatic cycling results revealed that Zn, Mg and Co doped SnO2exhibits high capacity with good cycling performance than the pure SnO2. Among all samples, Co doped SnO2 shows highest capacity and good cycling performance with 83% capacity retention. The rate capability of the Mg and Co doped sample shows higher capacity and better reproducibility when compared with the pure and Zn doped SnO2 samples. The better performance of the Mg-SnO2 sample suggests new insight for its further studies on the intermetallic interactions between the Mg-Sn species. The outstanding electrochemical performance of Co doped SnO2 can be attributed to Co-Sn intermetallic interactions, the nanocrystalization and the stable structure that originates afer the incorporation of Co in to the SnO2 sites which results in minimum volume change during the electrochemical reactions. Further insitu studies are needed to understand the detail electrochemical reaction mechansms.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we show that magnesium and cobalt doped SnO2 (Mg-SnO2 and Co-SnO2) nanostructures have profound influence on the discharge capacity and coulombic efficiency of lithium ion batteries (LIBs) employing pure SnO2 and zinc doped SnO2 (Zn-SnO2) as benchmark materials. The materials were synthesized via sol-gel technique. The structural, chemical and morphological characterization indicates that the Zn, Mg and Co dopants were effectively implanted into the SnO2lattice and that Co doping significantly reduced the grain growth. The electrochemical performances of the nanoparticles were investigated using galvanostatic cycling, cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy 3 (EIS). The Co-SnO2 electrode delivered a reversible capacity of around 575mAhg -1 at the 50 cycle with capacity retention of ~83% at 60 mAgcurrent rate. A capacity of ~415 mAhg when cycling at 10 mA gand >60% improvement in coulombic efficiency compared to the pure compound clearly demonstrate the superiority of Co-SnO2electrodes.The improved electrochemical properties are attributed to the reduction in particle size of the material up to a few nanometers, which efficiently reduced the distance of lithium diffusion pathway and reduction in the volume change by alleviating the structural strain caused during the Li intake/outtake process. The EIS analyses of the electrodes corroborated the difference in electrochemical performances of the electrodes: the Co-SnO2 electrode showed the lowest resistance at different voltages during cycling among other electrodes.
